p: Malaria is a global threat contributing to serious sociocultural and health issues in humid and tropical regions [ 103, 104]. Chemotherapy reported the antimalarial activities of S. alata could be linked to quinones, alkaloids, and terpenes [ 105, 106]. Quinones isolated from S. alata significantly displayed in vitro antiplasmodial activity, against Plasmodium falciparum via the microdilution test of Desjardin [ 107]. Terpenes isolated from S. alata leaves displayed pronounce in vitro antiplasmodial assays against P. falciparum in ethylene glycol-water fractions. Significant activity was observed at concentration below 1 µg/ml [ 108]. The appraisal of aqueous leaf extract justifies the ethnomedical applications of S. alata as remedy for malaria and fever. The leaf extract considerably inhibited 3D7 strain of the P. falciparum parasite in Wistar mice [ 109].
